results.byline: By Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott
results.title: Best Movies of 2020
results.abstract: The screening rooms were closed. The festivals were virtual. The blockbusters were in storage. Even so, our critics found abundant and inspiring signs of cinematic life in the pandemic.

results.title: A Costly Quip Angers Chinese Moviegoers, and a Film Is Yanked
results.abstract: “Monster Hunter” disappeared from theaters in China after online critics labeled a snippet of dialogue — a pun about knees — racist and called for a boycott.
The Netflix drama “Mank” suggests that Herman J. Mankiewicz, credited along with Orson Welles, primarily wrote the script. But that has long been debunked by scholars.
results.title: Who Wrote ‘Citizen Kane’? It’s No Mystery

results.abstract: Kemp Powers is the co-director of “Soul” and screenwriter of “One Night in Miami,” but his collaborators may not know just how much of himself is in those films.

results.abstract: The director and cast, including Al Pacino, Sofia Coppola and Andy Garcia, look back at making “Part III,” which has been re-edited (and retitled) for its 30th anniversary.

results.abstract: Billy Wilder called her “the greatest film discovery since Audrey Hepburn,” and she made an immediate splash in two 1961 movies, when she was only 19.
results.title: Pamela Tiffin, Movie Star Who Shone Brightly but Briefly, Dies at 78
Roald Dahl’s Family Apologizes for His Anti-Semitism
results.abstract: The author, who died in 1990, made several disparaging comments about Jews during his lifetime. “Those prejudiced remarks are incomprehensible to us,” the family said in a statement online.

multimedia.copyright: Ronald Dumont/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
multimedia.caption: Roald Dahl in 1971. “We hope that, just as he did at his best, at his absolute worst, Roald Dahl can help remind us of the lasting impact of words,” the family said in its statement.

results.title: What to Watch: Modern Takes on Noir
Fernando Solanas, Argentine Filmmaker and Politician, Dies at 84
results.abstract: He helped propel a new wave of politically charged moviemaking and served as a lawmaker. He died of complications of the coronavirus.

multimedia.caption: Ferdinand Solanas at a news conference in Geneva in 2004. A filmmaker-turned-politician, he was best known for the movie “Sur,” which won him a best director award at the Cannes Film Festival in 1988.

results.title: A Cinematic Love Letter to Denmark’s Drinking Culture
results.abstract: Thomas Vinterberg’s “Another Round” explores the highs and lows of the Danes’ love of alcohol, at a time when their hard-drinking habits are under new scrutiny.

results.title: Who’s Who in ‘Mank’: A Guide to the Real-Life Players
results.abstract: The Netflix drama about the making of “Citizen Kane” features characters based on Hollywood writers, studio executives and others. Here’s what they were really like.

Best Performances of 2020
results.abstract: One day, we’ll look back on this year and bawl. But we should also remember that there were professionals out there who dared to bring joy to our screens.

multimedia.caption: The best performances of 2020 include, clockwise from center, Moses Ingram and Anya Taylor-Joy in “The Queen’s Gambit,” Amanda Seyfried in “Mank,” Aunjanue Ellis in “Lovecraft Country,” Maxwell Jacob Friedman in All Elite Wrestling and Marylouise Burke in “Ozark.”

results.abstract: The last Bee Gee looks back at his wide-ranging catalog of hits, and ahead to an album of duets that spotlights his first love, country music.
results.title: Barry Gibb Has a Mission: ‘Keep the Music Alive’
